article_text:
Sioux Falls, SD

A Sioux Falls elementary school recently celebrated a birthday. Robert Frost Elementary School just turned the big 50.

Retired teacher Deborah Hansen walked through a newly renovated hallway where her classroom once stood more than 20 years ago.

She returned back to Robert Frost Elementary to celebrate the school's 50th anniversary.

"All the excitement, and the children and you remember all the good times you had teaching here," Deborah Hansen, retired teacher, said.

The celebration capped off with the principal from 1965 unveiling a new school sign. The staff also highlighted the time that's passed since the school opened.

Hansen said a lot has changed since she last taught at the school in 1988, including the building's size.

"It's now a very large elementary school compared to what it was when I came," Hansen said.

Staff said the building has had three-different renovations since the doors opened 50 years ago.



A growing number of students have sparked many other building add-ons.

"The latest one we added rooms for our challenge center that moved over here, a science room, and then we added four new classrooms for our kindergarten and first grade wing." teacher Amy Dreke said.

Most parents say the buildings expansion is a plus for their students.

Staff say they've been serving 50 years of academic excellence at Robert Frost, and there looking to serve 50 more.

Teachers say the building updates will continue to make the school a great place to learn for students.
